review_title: Avoid this company and their downward spiral.
pros: some of my peers are excellent people to work with. Benefits are ok
cons: This organization has no idea how to manage money. They've been in trouble for years and have continued to overspend. Leadership claims to follow their core values but their actions are completely the opposite. The CEO gave himself a $900,000 raise last year while everyone else got nothing in terms of bonuses and tiny 2.5% salary increases even for excellent performance. The top level leaders are way out of their league, having never led an organization of this size prior to coming to MultiCare. This organization needs new leadership and a new vision. Acquiring Yakima Valley memorial hospital while the rest of the organization was losing hundreds of millions of dollars made no sense. They like to keep people around who agree with leadership, people who don't rock the boat, which means their values of honesty and integrity are lies. Employee satisfaction scores have plummeted, staff are incredibly overworked, and they are cutting corners everywhere just to survive. This organization is about to crumble and fall. Don't risk your career by signing on here.

You get pulled to work at other locations. You are expected to do the work for your provider and that clinic, ordering, med log etc. lead duties without being paid lead pay. You have one provider in your clinic you are responsible for and because they cant keep staff you have to manage the in basket and all orders for another provider at another clinic. Again, not being paid for it! You are just a number.

pros: None. This place is terrible.
cons: Management was among the worst i've ever worked for. I was sexually harassed and they asked me if I had accepted a pair of headphones from the man who sexually harassed me?! He tried to give me his old iPhone headphones, I already had some and didn't want his so I said no, this was months before I reported his sexual harassment to the company. They showed me no support and even went as far as to say that because I didn't disclose the headphone information, which I didn't even remember and wasn't relevant to the situation anyway, that I wasn't being forthwrite and therefore they determined there was no sexual harrasment taking place. They even refused to look at the text messages he sent me and another co worker. I walked out of the meeting crying and was so disgusted I quit shortly after.

pros: Good Cafeteria food options and good options for coffee. The clinical staff are Amazing at what they do, especially at Tacoma General and Mary Bridge Children’s Hospital.
cons:
I had a toxic leader who was clearly prejudiced against me from the start. Even though they rarely observed me performing my job and I was the highest performer on the team, they repeatedly found trivial things to write me up for. I received little orientation and support while performing in a highly stressful and high-profile role. They pretended to be kind while actively working to destroy my reputation and future career prospects with MultiCare. They were narcissistic, didn't listen, too politically correct, out of touch, and weaponized the "MultiCare values" to accuse me of not performing to their constantly changing expectations.

While I was getting written up for a ridiculous assertion by my manager, they bragged that they had "written up over 40 employees" in their last 15 years of leadership. When I asked how many had grown through the process and gone on to stay with MultiCare, I was told "0". HR will never side with you. They are only there to protect their poor leaders and keep Multicare from getting sued. Once a leader at MultiCare decides you don't fit their strict mold, they will mercilessly work to destroy you.

Additionally, Multicare has a horrible retirement plan. It takes forever to receive the employer contribution (typically in March), causing you to miss out on potential gains. It takes over a year to be eligible, then three years before vesting.

I loved the work I was doing but had to leave due to a toxic leader.

We are encouraged to be safe and be better and reporting incidents and abuse etc is encouraged and not ignored. Work life balance- at least in my department is greatly encouraged as this prevent burnout. MHS gives a lot to their community through fundraisers and sponsoring events in the area. My manager is excellent. She has great communication, follow through, career and personal support. Our team truly embodies the MHS values especially kindness and collaboration. Higher ups seem to really listen to here when she brings our concerns. CEO is quick to respond with statements about national affairs (both cultural and political) when appropriate. I feel supported, safe, heard, and valued.
cons: It took a long time to get a full time when I was part time. They say their goal was to get me fulltime since that's what I requested but it took much longer to execute it than I thought. For me it was 4 years. My manager had been advocating for this for a year but they continued to only approve enough partial FTE and per diems to give me full time hours but without the benefits. finally have a 0.8 FTE with benefits and I am very thankful. This is one of the biggest reasons we have had recent hires leave our department. They left for Fulltime + benefits.

review_title: Overall a great company to work for that truly cares about its' employees.
pros: Flexible scheduling, time off is always approved provided you have coverage + hours in your PTO bank, remote working options, fun events throughout the year (e.g. we recently had an affordable, virtual streaming concert evening benefiting the community) and healthy@work programs which results in free self-health insurance through MultiCare plans.
cons:
- Decisions that affect our department processes are usually made at the higher management levels and could be improved by including the involved staff's knowledge from the start or by rounding with all departments affected by the change. I do recognize that MultiCare has improved in this area the last few years. 

- Healthcare personal choices, like the covid-19 vaccine, are being heavily pushed on a weekly basis which is unnerving as an employee. Per our American right I can refuse any vaccine if my health proves it is not necessary to my long-term healthcare plan; my healthcare choices are HIPPA confidential between my doctor and myself. In my opinion, all those with health risks should vaccinate themselves privately to ensure their personal safety, but even the at-risk have that right to choose to refuse treatment privately. An employer should not pressure or publicize our healthcare choices and while they've promised not to terminate non-vaccinated employees these notices feel more threatening as time goes on.

pros: MultiCare is a local health system that is dedicated to the community it serves and those the it employs. While no system is perfect they continuously try to maintain high standard in patient care. They also recognize that they have to take care of those on the front lines to make sure that patients get the right care. They try to remain competitive in compensation and benefits while being fiscally responsible so that they can continue to grow. The upper level leadership truly believes in their core values. In my experience they look for ways to move people up when it is appropriate.
cons: Like most larger systems or employers connecting the dots between decisions made at the C suite levels and the perception of the front line staff doing the work can be challenging. Sometimes leaders forget that staff needs to know the why to better understand and get on board. Keeping pay rates competitive is a challenge in this market.

job_title: Patient Access Tech in Tacoma, WA
pros: Great benefits, decent pay, room for growth, great supervisors
cons: Covid has caused some burnout, so take your vacations and use pto.

pros: It is a job where you will some money.
cons:
MultiCare is the worst excuse for a health system and employer I've ever seen in my life.

They utterly failed to protect staff and employees during the covid-19 pandemic. Antivax, antimask attitudes were rampant among support staff and leadership. When I brought up concerns about this, they went nowhere, ultimately because almost everyone all the way up (in my clinic) shared the same political opinions. One of our management staff got covid, and the day she returned from her sick leave, she was still not wearing a mask when speaking to staff. When I reported my concerns about a comment my director had made, she pulled me into her office and accused me of lying and slander.

Human Resources is a joke, by the way--I sent them screenshots of my manager directly violating written MultiCare policies about work hours, and they essentially told me it was an interpersonal issue. Any issue I sent them was quickly closed without any serious attempt to resolve it. They don't stand by their own policies. I genuinely have no idea what they do all day. Compliance is also a joke. MultiCare was temporarily out of compliance because they didn't keep up on state mandates regarding masking/vaccination attestation in workplaces, and didn't care or appreciate when I warned them. It's fixed now that state mandates have changed again, but my point stands. These things should be a priority; they should have had staff dedicated to it. MultiCare does not attract the best and brightest. If you are intelligent, hardworking, ambitious--GO ELSEWHERE. 

MultiCare failed to prioritize covid vaccination for patients. Processes moved very slowly and patients were not informed of changes to policies and procedures in an organzied manner. Patients were constantly confused and upset because every clinic enforced masking, distancing, and visitation policies differently. I was personally creating handouts to keep patients up to date on where they could get covid vaccines and tests, since Multicare's information was almost always out of date. Why was a receptionist responsible for this? Again, that should have been a priority from above. 

Pay is abysmal for the workload. Rather than increasing pay and staffing during the pandemic, MultiCare effectivelyi decreased it. I know in my clinic, they took away our front office lead position altogether and asked me to do more work for less pay than our former leads. Just another way to penny pinch! We used to have coffee and water; leadership quickly took this away. Yes, we had to pay for our own drinking water while at work--we pooled money for a water cooler, and took turns buying and lugging in jugs of water from Walmart. This is unacceptable. (It is technically legal since they provide tap water and tap water in Tacoma is safe to drink!) Multicare will screw over employees any way they can as long as it's technically legal, basically. 

They hire new doctors without support staff to help them. One nurse will be doing the work of three nurses. Patients will be scheduled when no one is there to room them or see them. Lines and lobby crowding make it impossible to maintain a six foot distance. It's a safety issue after safety issue, but management doesn't care. Nurses are having emotional breakdowns and doctors are working hours upon hours of uncompensated admin time. 

MultiCare will claim they're a not-for-profit hurting for money when they have hundreds of millions in expendable assets. It's a shameful, shameful lie. They could hire and retain more staff if they wanted, but they don't. They will take advantage of your humanity and passion for medicine. You will not be rewarded for hard work. You will be forced to choose between your own sanity and your patients' needs. Please do not work here. 

And guess what, MultiCare? After you spent six months gaslighting me every time I had a concern, and trying to manipulate me into believing I wasn't worth an extra $1.50/hr, I found a job that pays nearly twice as much! And they even provide luxuries such as filtered water for their staff. It is possible after all!

job_title: Sterile Processing Tech in Spokane, WA
pros:
Dept manager is top notch! She's not a micro-manager but is available to help if needed. Coworkers are an interesting bunch: a variety of personalities that, for the most part, work well together. Day shift handles a lot of turnovers and IUS instrumentation. Evening shift is extremely busy, processing the bulk of the day's instrumentation plus loaner trays for the next day. Night shift handles sterilizer testing and finishing any trays needed for the next day.

Aside from one or two gossipy meanies, folks are helpful, patient and generally act like adults. Lots of experienced techs in this department, so it can feel intimidating to a newbie. However, folks are willing to share what they know and are passionate about this career field. 

This department is unionized through SEIU 1199NW. Their website has copies of the union contract, including starting wages and pay scale.

At times, the surgical schedule really ramps up and instruments pile up. Overtime will be approved (but not mandatory) so you can get that extra money! 

This was my favorite sterile processing place to work in. Although not every coworker was my cup of tea, I felt like the dept as a whole was a second family to me. I really grew to care about each coworker and was heartbroken to leave them.
cons:
As with any sterile processing dept, we dealt with staffing shortages, unrealistic expectations from the OR and surgeons, instrument shortages, and busybody OR folks overstepping boundaries. 

The mentality of "do more with less" was really taxing at times, but those expectations came from high-up leadership, not dept management. It seemed like Deaconess leadership was awfully keen on growing their cash cow (surgery) without improving sterile processing capabilities (and surgery can't happen without sterile processing).

cons: I can't speak for all departments but when clinic after clinic and department after department decide that a Union is the only way to receive what Multicare says it provides shows self, others and the community something different. In my experience (through watching it happen to others), open door policy means- "the door is open, I will hear you talk and then dismiss all you said..." With department directors on top of department managers on top of department leads on top of department supervisors who then all manage (instead of lead) the "workers" there is a continuing difficulty with accountability and an increasingly consistent scapegoating. Amazing professionals are parented...not lead by example and integrity. Again, this may only be exclusive  within the psychology/community behavior programs. The turn over is atrociously high, in almost ALL departments with in behavioral health, especially adult services.

review_title: Multicare does not care about its employees!
pros: Great coworkers and GREAT providers!!
cons: Understaffed. Never got breaks or a lunch.

pros: Employees are really nice and helpful
cons: Pay could be a lot better

job_title: Licensed Practical Nurse in Anaheim, CA
pros: great place to work and grow
cons: none that i know of

pros:
- Fantastic coworkers. I can't say enough about some of the wonderful people (in all disciplines) I've had the honor to work with. 
- Some inspirational leaders who spawned a motivation within myself I didn't think I had. 
- Generous benefits and PTO accruals. 
- A multitude of opportunities for professional development through course offerings.
- Tuition reimbursement.
cons:
- Lack of advancement. I've been a part of MultiCare for nearly eight years. I have a stellar record, the experience and the required education to propel me in the right direction. Despite all that, every pursuit to move up (or even outward) was unsuccessful. With the exception of one, every job I interviewed for was filled by an external candidate. Why not cultivate the talent you already have and provide them with the chance to grow? 
- Unqualified leaders. Self-explanatory, for the most part. How can you expect a department to perform at its best if the leader is unprofessional, disengaged and incompetent? Granted, there is a big cultural shift to improve the leadership but it will take a long time until all those leaders are phased out and replaced with new leaders who embody the new culture.
- No transparency. So many changes happened in the last couple years...layoffs, re-organization, outsourcing and who knows what else is coming.

job_title: Licensed Practical Nurse in Tacoma, WA
pros: Multicare has been my home for more than 15 years. I am proud when i am asked where i work and i tell them multicare. I love the families that we care for. Multicare has put many check to ensure that care is provided to the community with financial aid programs. We have brought in personnel that help patient maneuver around the insurance enrollments. We residency programs to train new doctors.
cons: More emphases placed on advanced provider growth and for RN development. We need more assistance for MA and LPN to advancement. when having to work full time and go to school there is no room for family. Staffing is cut short in clinics and the need has to be shown for more than a year out be fore you hire out. Health care is tough lets not make it harder by working the staff to bare bone when live are at stake

pros: i learned SO much, i can hang drips and deal with drains all day any day. I can Care for complex crashing patients and have Confidence in my thought process. Amazing time managemen skills now. learned real fast how to cut corners.
cons: HORRIBLE Management, Manipulative, disrespctful, and unsupportive. Demanding and rude. patients are also demanding and rude. inappropriate assignments. Blanant favoritism. whoever makes the schedual DOES NOT work with you at all. might as well as not had an orientation for as much as the "ease you into things". 5 Months expereicce? that good enough to be charge nurse.

job_title: RN, Bsn in North Puyallup, WA
pros: Some of the nurses here are wonderful people.   They work hard and are very dedicated.
cons: As another reviewer said,   "Because its a union company, it is hard to flush out lazy employees."    I would add that everyone seems to walk on eggshells at MC.  They seem afraid to speak up about lazy employees and those not doing their jobs.   Management seems very concerned about what patients think ...but much less concerned about those giving the care.     Time for a flush out of time wasters and lazy under producers.     If staff wasn't so afraid to speak up maybe some of the recent events at GS wouldn't have happened.

pros: Great benefits, decent hourly pay and shift differentials (you could make more elsewhere but the benefits are worth it), good staff to patient ratios even for CNA, great environmental services team so really clean, opportunities for overtime, many good learning opportunities for those CNAs interested in advancing in the industry.
cons: Management tends to micromanage too much. The drug test also tests for nicotine and they have a strict no smoking policy for employees (thought some still do and have been grandfathered in). They keep going back and forth between being strict and lax on their tattoo/piercing/haircolor dress code policies and it was really annoying every time they would try to revert back to the 20 year old dress code policy.

pros: Outsource company honored current pay and seniority.
cons: Outsourced coding after assuring employees it was only done on the other side of the state because they couldn't find enough qualified coders to fill the openings they had.  Top management stuck with that story until the day they announced to our fully staffed department that we were being outsourced as well because that was the "MultCare standard".

review_title: Multicare has been a great company to work for!
job_title: CT Technologist in Spokane Valley, Spokane, WA
pros: Great pay and a very friendly HR staff. My department was great before multi-care stepped in and took over but the people I get to work with on a daily basis at Deaconess Hospital really make the work environment amazing!
cons: I think the medical benefits could be a little better and a little less expensive. They should include a couple of free massages every month as well as some naturopathic options

review_title: MultiCare Health System is a good place to work
pros: As the largest employer in Pierce County, MultiCare offers multiple opportunities for those interested in health care.  The senior leadership is committed to growth and makes efforts to communicate with those in upper management.  The benefits remain quite good, especially in a time when so many employers are cutting them.
cons: For those like me who do not possess degrees in health care, even though I possess the education, qualities and abilities to excel at my job, my compensation is lower than if I possessed, say, a degree in nursing, for example.  Like most major hospital-based systems, the departments generating the most revenue receive the most rewards; thus, smaller departments, even though increasing their revenue stream and making a positive contribution to the system, receive little recognition for bottom line improvement.

pros: Good Pay and Benefits. Great Coworkers
cons: Management is only concerned with themselves. Bonus program called Gainshare only pay out to a few departments yet management get a bonus regardless.  HR is only available by electronic communication. Yearly employee survey results are not shared with staff.  CEO does go to many locations and meets with employees but my department coworkers have never been able to attend.   New annual review for all staff changed from anniversary date to all employees reviewed in May 2018 yet still waiting to know when raises will start and if raises will retroact to Anniversary date or July 1.

review_title: Inpatient Behavioral Health management needs to change ASAP!
job_title: Geriatric Psychiatry Employee in Auburn, WA
pros: Multicare has great values of Kindness, Collaboration, Stewardship, Integrity, and Respect.  Nurses, CNA, and professional staff who provide direct patient care are kind, compassionate, and doing their best to collaborate & provide excellent care. Patients are wonderful to work with. Housekeeping staff is super.
cons: Staff turn over is high. Morale is low. Micromanagement & fear-based management style, which is NOT in alignment with Multicare values. Favoritism. Minimal opportunities & support for professional growth & development. No attention to "caring for the caregiver." Lack of resources to provide quality patient care. Poor budgeting of finances.

review_title: Challenging But Rewarding Work in a Toxic Environment With Profound Turnover!
job_title: Mental Health Professional in Puyallup, WA
pros: MultiCare Health System at large is a decent organization to work for. It offers great health care benefits at affordable costs and is a well known and generally well respected health care system. Behavioral Health in particular, is a challenging but rewarding place to work if you enjoy serving clients with persistent mental illness. If you need clinical experience, it's a great starting place.
cons: Behavioral Health in particular has a high incidence of turnover because of the nature of work involved. Unfortunately, in recent months the turnover rate is increased exponentially because of poor management, poor working conditions, and a failed attempt to unionize. The later exposed an incredible divide between not only line-level workers, but also between line-level workers and management.

review_title: Could be great with a make over
job_title: Licensed Practical Nurse in Puyallup, WA
pros: Great doctors, good benefits, love most of the staff that I work with,  I have the equipment that I need to do my job
cons: Short staffed ALL THE TIME! If someone quits, it has to be justified to refill the position.. Then you have post the job, wait a week to even offer a job, that's if you can find a good applicant, then they have to start on a pay period... On and on so at the minimum... It could be 4-6 weeks to replace someone. Remember, we still have to justify filling the position. Multicare believes in profits and not getting sued over good patient care. We are supposed to see more patients with less staff and better customer service.

review_title: Decent hospital with terrible 'good old times ' mentality
pros: Good bedside staff. Most of bedside people genuinely care about their patients. But old timers managers tried to run the show like it's their mom and pop business. Harsh on new hard workers and easy on their good old buddies. It's gets old eventually. Multicare does annual survey but never follow ups on the results. It gets frustrating and people just leave.
cons: Terrible lower level management, benefits. Good place to work for if you do not have other options and do not want to drive to far places. But retirement plans are sub par, health benefits are expensive and gain sharing is hard to achieve for bedside staff. Executives still gets big bonuses and multicare gets to keep it's not for profit status. Government and corporate collaboration at its finest.

pros: Good benefits, collaboration between departments, experience in a fast paced environment, opportunity for growth, excellent educational opportunity. Working with patients and endeavoring to assist in their health and overall well-being was a positive life changing experience. Team work a necessity, feels like you gain a second family.
cons: A lot of cutbacks, and lack of consistency. Increase of double the work for half the pay, old employees fired while younger newer employees hired in order to cut costs. Employees very overworked in turn affecting moral and motivation within department. Transparency very limited, management within particular departments not often present.

pros: The people you work with day to day become your family. The organization has seen tremendous growth over the last few years which is Great! Alot of flexibility within your job and schedule.
cons: HR does not apply the same guidelines across the board for growth opportunities and promotions. HR has way too much control and leaves very little to the management within your dept. Fellows/interns get favored in this company. Very hard to get promoted and grow. Management turnover is very, very high. Too much waste in the organization. Consultants run the show at Multicare.

pros:
The organization's mission and values are good ones.
Good people with good intentions at all levels of the organization.
Competitive salaries for hourly employees.
Opportunities for growth and development
cons:
Too many competing priorities making it difficult to find satisfaction in doing a job well.
Focus has become grow, grow, grow, without the support system in place to manage the growth. 
Unrealistic expectations- do more with less and keep smiling....
No work-life balance for salaried employees.

job_title: Registered Nurse in Conneaut Lake, PA
pros: Benefits and compensation are okay. Some of the people are the most wonderful people you will meet in your life.
cons: People in management are antisocial and will bully you. Managers are often underqualified and don't possess the experience, knowledge or credentials they should and in turn don't support their staff. I reported a director who was verbally abusive to staff and has a history of making lewd remarks (i.e., ageist, racist, and sexist). I will never make that mistake again. I suffered the repercussions of a very punitive system, and was reassured that what I said was confidential. I feel so overstressed and overworked that I will be leaving the organization soon. The turnover rate is very high. Engagement surveys are nonsense as a director had the lowest scores in all of Multicare and yet he still continues to work there despite multiple complaints. He is also the cause of the turnover and Multicare continues to protect him.

job_title: Home Health Case Manager in Tacoma, WA
pros: Large company, Great benifits! (That was an overall review of the corperation.) Home health  flexible hours, no call. One on one with patients. Better than average mileage, phone and computor charting.
cons: This is for the Home health division only: No work life balance for full time employees, expect to work 12+ hrs and if you put down the actual amt of hours you work you are put in the line of fire ( most employees will not put in actual hrs worked) Too many cheifs not enough indians and most of the "chiefs" will tell you contradict each other when it comes to what needs to be accomplished. Scheduling is a nightmare!! High turnover rate...Bully supervisors... If you try to transfer they can and will deny your request due to staffing needs.Be careful voicing your opinion or you risk be placed on "the list" and micromanaged until you quit.

review_title: Multicare doesn't care about the patients or staff. Bottom line is money. Evil and greed are Multiscare's values.
pros: The people that work here for the most part are great. Benefits are okay.
cons: Multicare will stop at nothing for money. They are a white collar sweatshop. They masquerade as a not for profit and yet the CEO makes millions while they lay off housekeepers and cafeteria staff. There are sociopaths in management and don't waste your time going up the chain of command or using their hotline. They do NOTHING and your supervisor will know what you report.  A nurse who was witnessed assaulting a patient still works there. While an investigation was going on the nurse was permitted to continue working. They are notorious for cover ups, Google it and see the number of lawsuits they've had.

review_title: Worth it at the end of the day
job_title: Medical Social Worker in Tacoma, WA
pros: Work for an agency that helps people at the most vulnerable time of their life in their own home. Agency supports patient choice and is a non-profit (instead of a faith based health system). Independent work. Flexibility to limit amount of time interacting with negative forces in the company.
cons: Lot of turnover, high stress, high demand. Lot of people grumbling about how it used to be. All healthcare is struggling with medicare/medicaid cuts and changes in health insurance which ripples down to everyone's job. continually asking for more and more for less. No coverage for vacations/sick days. Poor management causes flux in census resulting in staff being low census'ed or way over booked. Work itself carries its own stress of accumulative grief.

review_title: Decent company, work outlook depends on your manager
pros: If your manager cares about the unit, you will likely enjoy the work. Coworkers are great and supportive, the work culture (in my experience) was positive and a strong community.
cons: Some of the managers only want to climb up the ladder at any cost, these people don’t care about your or your safety. Yet somehow they progress up where they want to be. That is a head scratcher to me.

pros:
So far, everything sounds good. We remain optimistic.
Hoping Multicare values experienced advanced practice providers - $50K tuition reimbursement for new grads is great, but what about retaining the loyal, experienced folks that didn't jump ship, the ones that stayed through the hard times because we felt an obligation to our community, our organization? APP salaries need to be increased to fair market level - over the years we have been asked to be patient, be patient... hopefully we won't be waiting too much longer.
cons: So far, no cons, we remain hopeful.

job_title: Multicare Health Systems in Tacoma, WA
pros: Staff were consistently inconsistent.  They did the best that they could but did not have the tools nor the initiative to do so.
cons: Leadership was fantastic when the cameras were on, but awful and toxic and downright mean when not.  Patients were not as well taken care of, not by the staff nurses, but by the management setting the "rules".  Too much was expected by too few people and most of the few were entrenched and not encouraged or wanted to do what was the right thing for patients.  Too much thinking about Rules and the Finances that patient care for sure took a back seat.

pros: There are NO PROs to report.
cons: I worked at MultiCare for just under 5 months - I was hired for what I thought was a full-time -long term employment opportunity.  It turns out, that I was used for my expertise to train staff and assist the organization in succeeding in their necessary assessments.  After the staff was trained and the assessments were passed and over, I walked in a few days later and without any warning  was told to collect my things from my office and escorted out of the building with the reasoning of "Thank you for your service here, however your position is no longer needed."    Soon there after I discovered that this is apparently a common practice with the MultiCare organization.

review_title: Leadership Incompetence & Unprofessionalism at Tacoma General
pros: Great hours, good benefits, bonuses
cons: Inexperienced Leadership, Rude, Untrustworthy,  Condescending

job_title: Licensed Practical Nurse in Tacoma, WA
pros: There are a variety of areas to work in, extensive training and great benefits,  They provide a shuttle service thats convinent and easy to use as well as providing bus passes and carpooling options for employee transport to work.  with gas prices continuing to rise this is a money saver for sure.
cons: I am sure there are some but I am not sure what they are now as I have not been there for a long period of time.  I am sure as time goes on I will have a better sense of what the cons are.  right now I cant really speak to that.

review_title: Great pros, but some really, really bad cons
pros:
MultiCare has given me some great opportunities, but I've definitely earned them. I've worked hard over the years and worked my way up. I appreciate their leadership development program, and feel that they definitely place a lot of effort into developing leaders. A big company means a lot of relationship building and movement can happen.

Excellent benefits! The pay is lower than local market, but the benefits are fantastic. Healthy at Work program, wellness fairs, contests, fun runs and marathons, discounts, shuttle and ride programs, tuition reimbursement...I could keep going.
cons:
Oh boy, where to start. For as much as MultiCare has given me, it has taken so much more.

Work life balance is talked about, but it's an expectation that you are available at all times, day or night. I often have to work through days off when my director needs something. I've given 110% but it hasn't always felt like it's enough.

The company itself goes through major upheaval on a fairly regular basis, where our jobs are at risk, and we worry about whether we will even have a job.  Reorganization, taking away positions, adding different positions, changing job descriptions, and lowering quality standards to meet the bottom line...all things that happen almost annually. 

Leadership could really communicate better. I hope they're working on that. Half the time it feels like no one knows what's going on.

A new CEO has brought serious change. The organization is cutting a total of $300 million dollars in operating costs over the next 3 years. The first $100 million came down last month and will be coming out of next year's budget. My department could be losing about 1/3 of our staff, maybe even more. We don't know, and that's the hard part. We have no idea what's happening, when it's happening, and how it's going to happen. We just know it's bad and it's right before Christmas.

review_title: Company is losing its work family culture
pros: The talented people who care about what they do and patient care. Continuing education. The salaries are very competetive. Work family culture. Employees work very hard.
cons: Politics among leadership at the cost of other's jobs and outsourcing many areas. Supposedly all in the name of patient care, but patient satisfaction scores do not improve and organization continues to have the highest pricing and costs in the state

pros: Great atmosphere in our department (Pediatric Weight & Wellness). Program Coordinator constantly looked for talent that helped to make the program team more skilled and dynamic. Was encouraged to network with other departments to provide a more cohesive mission for MultiCare. Good pay.
cons: Being such a small department we often were overlooked or forgotten about, which led to higher ups allowing other departments to start their own program that had the same mission as ours. In other words, lack of communication with other department leads and higher ups led to redundancy.

pros: If it is close to home and you can take the stress, it's a good place to work.  Compensation is better than other places.
cons:
Lack of parking!
Office politics and business as usual.
Mismanagement or lack thereof.  Once you are hired on, you would have to try really hard to get fired.
Patient care is lacking.
Stress, stress, stress...
Changes or "upgrades" to software make things slower or harder to use.  Getting something changed takes months, not weeks or just days.
There is a new CEO.
Currently they are cutting a ton of jobs and letting people go.

pros: Great company that offers great benefits and a great working environment. I work within a department that really is committed to doing excellent work and collaborates together exceptionally.
cons: Salaries...Have seen inconsistenties in regards to new jobs that are posted and approved but then Human Resources decides to review the position again even though they have reviewed an approved the position to offer it at a lower salary then it was posted as.

pros: A large company that emphasizes professional growth and development.  There are plenty of opportunities for advancement, and with such a large organization, it is hard to get bored.
cons: Day shift parking could be better.  There are shuttles that run on limited schedules, and they are no very helpful for staff coming from the north or folks working 12 hour shifts.  Also, you would think working for a healthcare organization, the insurance benefits would be stellar. They're not.

pros: Great team, concerned about their future.
cons: Unethical supervisor. Evil and not principles. Disloyal. Doesn’t care about the Organization , patients or staff. HR has no saying. Many employees loyal to the Hospital are not treated with respect. In my opinion the high end leaders are not aware of what happens in the departments. It’s a shame as many in the community we’re born there and see the Hospital as there family. But it’s not like that.

review_title: Working for incompetent manager who harbors incompetent, negative workers.
pros: Biggest employer in Pierce County.  Leader in the HealthCare industry, especially with Electronic Health Records.  Many people have worked there at least 20 years.
cons: When many people have worked there 20 years, there is not much new blood.  There is a "MultiCare Way" seat of the pants management style in the middle ranks.  Fresh ideas from the ranks are shot down before they go anywhere.  Even incompetent workers have a safe harbor.  Feedback is futile because of defensiveness of the "MultiCare Way."  Some concepts like "changing the oil" regularly seem so foreign it is very alarming.

review_title: Want to be a pharmacy tech here?
job_title: Certified Pharmacy Technician in Spokane, WA
pros:
Pharmacy technicians are union and have a great rep! If you are a nationally certified pharmacy tech you get a small bump in pay from the starting pay. Benefits are amazing. Health benefits start for full time employees after the first 30 days and include a 401k as well.  Scrubs can be provided by the hospital, but you can also wear your own as well. 
Breakfast in the cafeteria is great as well as they do offer the perfect bacon and many other things as well.
cons: Parking is not free, however it is VERY reasonable per month. But on the weekends the garages are open without having to pay.

pros: Loved my co-workers, and my duties.  The pay was fair.
cons: Extraordinarily stressful work environment, especially for RNs and those who work directly with patients (RNs beware: Unrealistic patient: RN ratio). Punitive and fear based management.   I had the highest productivity in my department (130%), but was pressured to do more, and was indirectly pressured to inflate my productivity.  When I reported that co-workers were inflating their patient contact time, (i.e. lying), and, therefore, the bill the patient got), I was given a cold shoulder and my supervisor refused to talk with me about it.  Also,  I reported a serious, continuous HIPPA violation: An investigation was done and problems found, but the reviewer had someone higher up make her tell me to "drop it".  After 12 years I left due to unethical practices, and unbearable management (80% of them).  RNs cry here regularly, due to overwhelming stress.  Your boss will throw you under the bus immediately, rather than investigate the concerns or perceptions of others.  This job is appropriate for beginning level employees who need experience and who can tolerate being treated with disrespect.  PATIENTS:  Keep someone with you to help you watch for medication errors, to clean you, to help you get to the toilet, and to help you.  Your poor RNs are far too busy, and cannot meet all of your needs.

job_title: Desktop Emergent Team in Tacoma, WA
pros: The staff here at Multicare are amazing and always uplifting. The morale in my department is high and the rapport is through the roof. The managers and supervisors on my team encourage you to do and be your best. Always willing to listen and give both creative and constructive feedback. I Love My Job!!!
cons: Unfortunately I cannot say anything bad about Multicare Health Systems. There is nothing is jothing really wrong with my department I work in or the individuals that I am currently working with.

pros:
-Great culture among coworkers. 
-Doctors work collaboratively with nurses. 
-Unit leaders and hospital administrators work to support the direct caregivers, and they care about our success.
-Management tends to listen and give the impression that they respect us.
cons: Upper leadership often make penny wise and pound foolish decisions that lead to transient pet projects. This causes unnecessary harm to productivity and moral.

review_title: Great Place To Work, Learn, and Grow
pros: Great Benefits, competitive pay, great teammates, and excellent mission!  MultiCare is very committed to promoting employees from within the organization.
cons: As with any large employer, it can be challenging to navigate through some of the bureaucratic layers.  I also find it disappointing to see the negative reviews on this site and attribute it to employees or former employees who are not accustomed to being held accountable.   People will always write a review when "dissatisfied"...

review_title: Nurse care manager- longevity, tenure and loyalty not valued. Not treated with integrity or respect. Not transparent.
pros: Well protected  by the union as a bed side nurse. Excellent benefits and perks and support
cons: Not protected as a  non exempt employee  used and abused and then discarded once salary cap reached Despite exemplary performance reviews yearly. Discrimination of age and gender.

review_title: Overall great place with many opportunities
pros: leadership support for nursing research and education with some tuition reimbursement. Great pay and benefits.  Many great, caring and supportive people, but it varies greatly by department.  Completely converted to EHR
cons: Some departments have a pervasive negative attitude ,and nonexistant teamwork, if you are observant you will be able to see it when you interview, if you see it explore options with other departments because this is the exception, not the rule.  Nursing is stressful overall, which is a con, but not specific to multicare.

job_title: Lifestyle Educator in Gig Harbor, WA
pros: Worked as a contractor so had some flexibility when needed to take time off. Organized environment with a teamwork mentality.
cons: Even though it is a Not for Profit - believe me that is always a misnomer. At times I was micromanaged and not treated like a responsible contractor. I was treated more like an employee. And in fact the positions were eventually made into employee positions and pay was cut in half.

review_title: Used to be a great employer.
pros:
Competitive Salary
Growing geographic footprint with ample opportunities.
cons: Work-life balance is not important in the organization.  There is no input from frontline staff regarding patient care and operations.

review_title: MultiCare was nice while it lasted, after leaving though happy to be separated.
pros: Patient Care focused, Expanding to provide more care. Direction of the company is very patient focused, "give them the pickle".
cons: Policy regarding PTO and EIT was not created to deal with EIT abusers but as an easy fix which takes away the ability to save vacation time if your position has high ratio of low censusing. HR is there to protect the company not the employees.

pros: There's always patients for the caseload.  The office staff are awesome, they do their best to be helpful.
cons:
Management has gone downhill over the past few years.. and more so over the past 2 years.  Too many managers  but no one knows exactly how to run the show.   Management is cold and uncaring,  no regard for employees.    They do not recognize the value of their employees.  Has turned into the typical corporate attitude.   Too many meetings that yield nothing productive except for added stress.  Poor support for clinical staff.
If not for the support staff in the office,  people would have left sooner.  still, high turnover clinical staff.

pros: The only reason I stay is the excellent care line staff and my desire to provide good patient care
cons: Extremely top heavy admin w unnecessary layers of high paid do nothings.the worst HR dept I have experienced in many years of health care work-HR admin  totally disinterested and above employees concerns and unconcerned about hiring excellent staff at community standard pay and raises are abysmal- lucky to get 2%/year. Truly awful HR administration

review_title: Be a management suck up...or your job suffers
pros:
Benefits (although getting worse every year)
Pay
cons: Management too concerned about “patient satisfaction” scores and billing for exams not necessary to address any interpersonal issues between employees. Every meeting is a push to improve survey scores to get a bonus that we rarely get anymore. Physicians and management get their bonuses while the people who work the hardest get nothing. Don’t dare speak up to the injustice to patients that’s occurring they will find ways to reprimand you. They praise an environment free of retaliation but it’s completely false. Can’t wait for my last day. TOXIC!!

pros: Wonderful Co-Workers who truly care about the Patients and Families.
cons: Management Turnover and Arbitrary implementation of new inefficient protocols and procedures. Inconsiderate of long term, established , and dedicated staff. Forced transition to Salary Pay to avoid paying out earned/deserved OT. Totalitarianism style Director/Leadership. Has become much more about the Bottom Line ( $$$) vs. Quality Patient Care.

pros:
Great coworkers
Work/Life balance
Providers are amazing to work with
cons:
Understaffed
Underappreciated 
Horrible benefits 
Pay is less than ideal
Management 
Policies

pros: Some of the employees are great
cons: The supervisor was just awful.  She never took the time to get to know any of her employees unless they worked first shift.  She gave preferential treatment, and even covered for employees that broke the rules, yet others she went after for the littlest thing.  Everyone not on first shift were very unhappy, and luckily got out.

review_title: A non-profit with its focus firmly on increasing profits at any cost these days.
pros: Wonderful place when I started years ago.  The employees really felt like family.  Management committed to staff and vice versa so staff retention was high.
cons: It is all about the bottom line these days.  Leadership numbers continue to increase while the rank and file are cut.  The stated goal is $100 million cost reductions per year. Achieving this is demoralizing staff and alienating physicians.  That's a dangerous combination.

pros: I experienced some wonderful, generous people and a few not so much. I received great on the job training and was welcome to help in other departments to learn more about the processes. Quick-learning, hard workers climbed quickly, especially working with IT-related positions.
cons: If you are not flexible or willing to grow and make yourself as useful as possible, your options and opportunities will be minimal.

pros: Great culture and good people.  Committed to professional development

review_title: Worst clinic I have EVER worked for!
pros: The company as a whole, had great health benefits, bonuses. That's about it.
cons:
The pay is below other competitors. 
When I left Multicare and went to another clinic in the area, my pay went up $4.83, I was told with my years of experience that is what I should be starting at. 

Management was horrible, the worst part. My review is similar to those before me. 

Definitely under staffed and over worked. At my location "Puyallup women's center" we were short staffed by 8 people, they stated the didn't like to use floats. So we took on the role of 1-3 people everyday. 
Often times I would work for 2 physicans seeing anywhere from 30-52 patients a day between two providers. 

Triage nursing was lazy, and it was encouraged. They would expect you to do all the nurse visits and work with 2 physicians. 

If you needed help, they would advise you "see if someone else can help you, if not do it when you are done". 
The bonuses sounded like a great incentive, but you soon learned it was tied into in obtainable goals. 
One being that every single employee get vaccinated against the FLU, they do not take into consideration those with allergies or strong views. So though you completed your vaccine, you still didn't meet your goal for the bonus. 

They encourage you to report any concerns or issues to management. And that there is a zero retaliation, that is 100% not true. I brought up concerns, about a lead RN nothing serious, but confidential. And the next day I was glared at, smart remarks made directly and indirectly at me. 
I was I unfriended and blocked on FB by her and several other coworkers following my complaint/ concerns. Which just was that I felt unsupported and she was unapproachable and whom could I go to instead. Turned out to be my worst decision. I stayed for 5 years with the company, and regretted everyday. 
Again management was the issue, the turnover rate was so significant that the leads, and supervisor couldn't handle the stress and all left the clinic in March/ 3016. 

I could go on and on. But again my review follows those above me, they are accurate and the same issues I had.

Oncology isn’t even oncology. It’s psych

review_title: Just do something else with your life.
pros: The Mission is important and the core values are well chosen.
cons:
Leadership has little if any regard for the core values and often they are more interested in the advancement of their own careers than the mission.

As a recent example which prompted this review, but is honestly just par for the course within this organization:

We have been under-staffed for two years.  My management just cancelled the job postings that had finally gone public because they wanted to move us to 12 hour shifts and those postings had been for 8 hour shifts.

Note that they are moving us to 12 hour shifts by 'posting' 12 hour jobs for us to apply to internally because they have rebid our department too many times recently and need to avoid doing so again.

The result is that one of my crew has had a mandatory double shift three weeks in a row now.  In fact we just had three mandatory double shifts back to back, which violates the union contract.  

This was a completely obvious and avoidable problem.  We warned them it would happen, but management didn't care.

The well being of the patients and / or staff was of zero concern to them.  Absolutely zero.

The 'work around' they proposed was so obviously never going to work it can't even be considered a genuine effort.  

The leader that decided to do this can be anticipated to face zero negative consequences, because employee morale and quality of patient care are as important to her bosses as they are to her.  

I realize this SOUNDS like its just the Tacoma General Telemetry Suite that has problems: it's not.  My work history has taken me through multiple Multicare facilities in multiple roles.  This is par for the course.  I am certain Susan Hensley is doing precisely what the leaders of the company would want her to do.  It is exactly the type of behavior I would expect from a MHS director.
